title: In California does enforcement of judgment begin 30 days after entry of judgment or 30 days after Notice of Entry of Default
question: In California does enforcement of judgment begin 30 days after entry of judgment or 30 days after Notice of Entry of Default Judgment is served on the defaulting party.
answers:
Judgment can be enforced immediately upon entry. Procedure for staying enforcement varies:
Civil Judgment:
Enforcement my be stayed by filing appeal or motion for reconsideration and posting bond.
Small Claims Judgment:
Automatically stayed and can be stayed upon request in conjunction with request, Judge may condition stay on posting bond.

the judgment may be enforced that day that it is entered. The filing of a Request to Enter Default is not a judgment, nor is entry of a default. What is enforced is the judgment.

There is an exception in Small Claims Court, where there is an automatic stay. And the court which enters the judgment can order a stay of execution, but this must be done by the judge in response to a request, and the judge can make the stay conditional, such as requiring the posting of a bond.

A default judgment can be enforced immediately, under the California Code of Civil Procedure. See my blog link below for options for a default judgment, if the defendant was not served properly and consult a debt collection DEFENSE attorney if you are the defendant/debtor.
It does not matter when the judgment notice was served for purposes of enforcement. There are certain time limits that do not commence until the judgment is served, but that was not your question.
